issues.description: The problem statement refers to the person's date-of-birth attribute as `dob` (line 3), but the template and solution code use the field name `birthday` (Person.getBirthday()/setBirthday(), field 'birthday' of type LocalDate). This naming mismatch between the textual specification and the provided code can confuse students when they look for the attribute to set or validate (e.g., when creating Person instances or when reading instructions referring to 'dob').
issues.suggested_fix: Make the terminology consistent. Either change the problem statement to refer to the 'birthday' attribute (and its getter/setter getBirthday/setBirthday) or rename the field and accessors in the template/solution code to use 'dob' consistently. Updating the problem statement to use 'birthday' is the least intrusive fix and keeps the provided code unchanged.

issues.description: The problem statement repeatedly refers to the persistence component as "PersonDAO" and instructs to call save(..) on `personDAO` (persistence layer / Part 4). The template and solution code use Spring Data naming: the interface is PersonRepository and the service field is named personRepository. This mismatch between the problem text (PersonDAO / personDAO) and the provided code (PersonRepository / personRepository) can confuse students about where to perform the save call and which identifier to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify terminology. Prefer the code's Spring Data name: update the problem statement to refer to PersonRepository (and variable `personRepository`) instead of PersonDAO / personDAO, and update the instruction text to say "call save(..) on personRepository". Alternatively, if you want to keep 'DAO' in the text, add an explicit note stating that the repository in the code (PersonRepository / personRepository) plays the role of the DAO.

issues.description: The problem statement describes the Person attribute as `dob` (date of birth), but the entity class in both template and solution uses the field name `birthday` (getBirthday()/setBirthday()). This identifier mismatch between problem description and code may cause brief confusion when students look for the field mentioned in the text in the provided Person class.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the wording consistent. Update the problem statement to mention the `birthday` field (or indicate that the date-of-birth is represented by the `birthday` attribute in the Person class). Alternatively, change the entity field to `dob` in the code if you prefer that identifier, but aligning the problem text to the existing code is less disruptive.
